Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Co-Robots for COMPUGIRLS - Culturally Responsive Robotics Education for Underrepresented Girls

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotics in the U.S. represents a multi-billion industry that is growing yearly. Currently a gap exists in the degree to which underrepresented populations participate in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics. The gap is especially severe in the area of robotics. This project lead by Marquette University is developing a culturally-relevant curricula to teach girls to program co-robots or humanoid robots that work in collaboration with people. The focus of the co-robots for COMPUGIRLS program is to expose girls from under-resourced areas to co-robotics using effective, culturally-relevant curricula and instructional approaches. This robotics education program is designed to expand the already extant NSF-funded informal education program, COMPUGIRLS, through supplementing this program?s curriculum with humanoid co-robotic activities. Project activities will be facilitated with the support of engineering majors from Arizona State University serving as near peer mentors. Collaborations between high school students and undergraduates are expected to increase girls' interest in robotics-related careers, and will yield co-robot projects with features that allow the co-robots to interface with girls and members in their communities.

The co-robots for COMPUGIRLS program offers an approach with a high potential to engage girls in the emerging field of co-robotics. The functioning of co-robots involves collaboration and interaction with people. Applications are expected to grow in significance in the future in such diverse areas as healthcare, agriculture, education, and advanced manufacturing. However, most current K-12 robotics activities are focused on task-based robot-to-robot competitions and electro-mechanical robots. These existing robotics programs face challenges in including girls, particularly those from underrepresented populations. The objectives of this project are to develop and study a culturally-responsive co-robotics curriculum in the context of COMPUGIRLS and involve girls in effective humanoid robotics programming. The approach taken is based on earlier COMPUGIRLS research results. The elements of cultural responsiveness consists of engaging girls at the interface of social and technical asset building in ways that require them to reflect on their intersectional identities both technical and social. Developing girls as technosocial change agents with skills in using technology to improve communities was found to be an important element in engaging girls in technological endeavors. This project will employ a mixed methods research design to determine the impact of engaging underrepresented girls in culturally responsive humanoid robotics using culturally relevant instruction and interactions. The research will advance the discipline of co-robotics by considering cultural aspects currently underexplored in robotics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-Robots for CompuGirls is a culturally responsive humanoid robotics program where underrepresented girls learn how to address social justice issues through programming humanoid robots.   The Co-Robots for CompuGirls program developed a culturally responsive, hands-on, inquiry and collaborative robotics curriculum with an emphasis on social justice.  The program successfully increased middle school girls' of color awareness of social justice, increased their awareness of humanoid robotics and computer programming skills and allowed them to synthesize social justice and robotics knowledge.  This program demonstrated to the girls how social humanoid robots could be used to address social justice issue by programming the robots to talk, move, and display emotions to interact with humans.The Co-Robots for CompuGirls program had three objectives:

  • Introduce middle school girls who are underrepresented in STEM to co-robotics
  • Study the impact of culturally responsive curricula on STEM robotics education for underrepresented girls
  • Empower girls to use technology to address social issues in their communities.

Girls living in Phoenix, Arizona, and Milwaukee, Wisconsin were recruited to participate in culturally responsive co-robotics curricula activities. These activities were organized into two main categories. The first category is culturally responsive computing humanoid robotics. Culturally responsive humanoid robotics is characterized by activities that allow students to engage in asset building, reflection and discussions that facilitate connecting to peers and family using social robotics as the underlying theme. These activities were designed to increase girls’ social justice awareness and general self-concept. While in the Co-Robots for CompuGirls program, girls had opportunities to reflect on their identities and assets, while engaging in hands-on inquiry-based activities in the context of robotics. Girls also had opportunities to participate in group discussions where they explored their identities and representation in society. 

The second category was the study of human-robot interaction.  Human-robot interaction activities included social humanoid robot programming, STEM learning, learning about human-robot interaction, and Python programming.  The girls also learned a visual programming language called Choreographe, which is used to program the NAO humanoid robot to perform various tasks. They also learned the basics of coding, including how to debug programs, use variables, and design algorithms. The co-robotics activities were designed to increase girls’ computer science self-efficacy and future intent to use technology.
The successful accomplishment of each objective was measured through an analysis of the co-robotics curricula modules, interviews of students, teachers and management interns, and an analysis of responses to pre-post surveys designed to measure computer science-self-efficacy, future intent to use technology, social justice self-concept, and general self-concept.  Based on our inferential statistical analysis, the results of the Co-Robots for CompuGirls program showed that the girls' knowledge of humanoid robotics and computer science, their future intent to use computers increased, and their social justice self-concept increased.
